title: Escaping Information Poverty through Internet Newsgroups

author: Laura Hasler, Department of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Strathclyde

segmentation: OK, so now for something completely different.

Basically we come to Usenet groups in discussion groups from the perspective of information, behavior, information seeking and information needs or not information seeking as might be the case in this situation.
So escaping information poverty through Internet newsgroups.
So first of all, I'm going to give a bit of context.
I'm going to tell you what information poverty is.
And then a little bit about online support, an online support groups.
Then I'll talk about our study and the aims of our research.
Going to how we collected our data and how we coded for our analysis.
Then present some findings in the three different sections.
Because we've got three main research questions and finish off with some conclusions.

OK, so information poverty basically in 1996 Alfredia Chapman proposed this theory, which basically tries to account for situations in which people don't approach other people for information when they need it information and support.
So there's a general unwillingness to ask other people for information due to social norms.
So basically certain types of information is deemed appropriate to a certain people.
And other types of information isn't.
Social norms kind of dictate what kind of can't be asked about linked to this.
The information seekers have a mistrust of the ability or interest of others to provide useful information that can help with their problems.

And they often way up benefits against potentially negative consequences, and often people don't risk revealing their information needs because they don't want others to find out something kind of damaging about them.
So for example, Chapman found that women living in a retirement home wouldn't express information needs about health issues about feeling lonely, about feeling a bit old and infirm.
Because the expectation in that situation was that you needed to be able to cope to look after yourself to stay in this in this accommodation.
And I ask these people, I tell him I have some kind of health problem.
I'm scared I might have to leave, so I'll keep quiet and I'll pretend everything is OK.
So secrecy and deception are used as self protective behaviors and this all feeds into a perceived lack of information sources on the part of the information seeker.
So this might be true or not true.
They might really not have any sources, or they just might not.
Think that they do.
So in relation to the.
Yes, let's think a little bit about online support groups.
So.
There's quite a body of literature on online support groups.
Are the benefits of using these groups to to find information and support the major thing.
Site is is is anonymity.
You can freely ask for information with people you don't know.

That's not to say that you don't tell them your name or things like that, because some people do put a heck of a lot of personal information in these posts, but it's more that you're not going to have to deal with them in any of the sphere of your life, so you can ask things that you might not ask anyone else.
Because you're embarrassed or there's some stigma attached or something like that.

Also, these groups potentially offer access to a large number of people from different places, so you're open to more opinions, more different types of help you might actually find what you're looking for, but these aren't just any old people.
These are people in similar situations because their groups draw people with similar interests or with similar problems together.

Other workers found that both information and emotional support are very prevalent in these groups so that they are good places to go to find help, and they're generally really positive and accepting places.
Generally people when they reply to you, they don't judge you.
They want to help you, and that's why they're there.
So other studies have looked at various things, mainly health related from cancer to alcohol abuse, to eating disorders to a rare liver disease, and these things come out across the board.
So in this context, our study, which is called what we can ask how information poverty manifests on the Internet.
We look at information sort and offered in news and discussion groups by people who are potentially suffering from this situation of information poverty.
So we've got 3 research questions for this part.
This is related to the information seeking and the support offered is the second part of the project.
So first of all, what information needs cause people to turn to the Internet for help?
Who do they hide?
These information needs from and why do they feel that they can only ask about these things in this place?
So to address this, we do qualitative content analysis.
Today.
We've done 114 relevant posts or post demonstrating information poverty from across discussion groups and we recorded them under these three broad headings corresponding to the research questions.
So overall we try and gain some insights into the use of Internet groups as the only source of help, because that's not been done before.
And also consider the theory of information poverty in a new setting in these groups, because it's mainly been looked at kind of in the physical world.
Where people have considered the Internet, it's been one of many information seeking methods.

So our data collection as I mentioned, we take posts from across Usenet, another discussion groups or previous work has taken one particular problem or one particular group of people and just looked at groups related to that.
But what we want to do is look across the board.
Basically anything people might be asking about in relation to information poverty.
So we use Google Groups and we search using key phrases.
So we started with a really simple indicator which we thought could capture potential situations of information poverty.
Obviously the things we found weren't all information poverty, so we had to read through and make sure we really got the ones where these people were hiding.
Information needs where where they couldn't ask anyone else.
So starting with I cannot tell anyone.
Obviously people might hide certain things from certain people.

Ann Chapman found that people wouldn't talk to the family and they wouldn't talk to the carriers in the retirement home, so we expanded to include other groups of people that might typically not be asked for help, such as parents, health care professionals, friends.
And we also because people phrase things in different ways.
We included a grammatical variants or so we didn't miss things out, and we used other communication verbs.
So things like talk to ask as well as tell.
And as we went through the post, we found some other people that we hadn't thought of searching for.
Their people would specify mum or they would specify therapist, not a doctor.
So we included these things to try and broaden the search a little bit.
But bear in mind that we're doing a kind of in depth qualitative thing.
We don't need millions of.
Post.
We also wanted to capture where people might not specify, so a general kind of desperation.
I just don't know where else to go.
I don't know what to do.

To only look for groups with more than 100 members, as these are much more likely to be considered public spaces and not private spheres.
And also we only took groups work that were openly accessible online, so no registration anything required.
So anyone can go in and look at what they post in addition to that we anonymize the post completely so we removed any identifying information at email at IP addresses.
Things like that, but also in the text itself.
Any names of.
So the people, because they might mention family friend names, they might mention where they live.
So we we used meta information to to replace these things.

We were interested not in kind of gauging the representativeness in discussion groups of the scale of information poverty, but more the kind of things people asked about why they go there so so we sample for diversity and we identified over 400 posts altogether using our small set of key phrases and our current analysis is based on 100.
14 of these.

It was both physical and mental health issues, but it was mainly mental health issues and you can see that this really ties into people not wanting to seek information from people they know.
About potentially stigmatising topics.
So I think All in all it shows that the information and support sort was on topics crucial to post his everyday lives.

Also, Chapman found that people tend to hide information needs that might make them seem less able to cope than other people.

Information wasn't just sought to help people by their self.
It was sought to help family and friends as well in quite a few cases.

Things like a grief and death and abuse were interesting because these things had built up over a long period of time and often it was the first time people were ever speaking about this or trying to deal with it.
But often there was a feeling that there was something wrong with the poster because because they can't manage to get over this thing that happened so long ago.

But it doesn't seem to get any better.
I won't go through all the.

So our second major finding was about who these topics were hidden from.

You notice that quite a lot of the time posters said that they just didn't feel they could approach anyone at all about their problems.
In this case as well, they didn't always specify who they couldn't ask, and this really tide in with the general.
I don't know where to go.
I don't know where to ask for help.
Where is everyone had some kind of information topic they were looking about.

Partner was a particularly interesting one because I think all the information is hidden from partner pretty much where about pregnancy and you might think that's the one person that people would seek support from.

She didn't want the baby, but he did and this is socially unacceptable in our relationship to to not want a baby.

Can other people give me advice?

I mentioned the unspecified label before when people don't have any sources of support at all.

All the sources that they don't approach.

So finally, the reasons why people feel they can only ask about their information needs online.

Things like this.
Another very popular one was that people just just don't know where else to go.

If other people should find out about these things.
Interestingly, we found cases where the groups were used as an additional source of information.

So for example, in the past people had approached the source that had been completely unhelpful and therefore now they will not approach that source again, and intermediate steps were people don't just use the group to try and deal with the problem, they use the group to ask for help on how they can talk to kind of the next person up so they realize they have hidden information needs they want to talk to their doctor or their parents or whoever.
But they don't know how to do it or their own confident and they use the group.
To try and get more information on this and that seemed initially to go kind of against the idea of information poverty.

Because OK, they're willing to seek information in the real world, but they just don't know how to do it, but I think it shows quite nicely that this situation isn't necessarily an absolute situation, but there's more of a spectrum and you can kind of claw your way out of it if you go and ask in the right places.
And in fact, her two other papers had found that people do use the Internet too.
To ask for help in other places as well, and it's not just not just an absolute situation.
